subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
In current form {{Han compound|曲|辰|t2=field|ls=ic}}. Top unrelated to {{lang|zh|曲}}, and previously two hands, one on either side of a bundle {{zh-l|*田}} – a farmer bringing goods to market, from the field {{zh-l|*辰}}.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
Probably {{der|zh|sit}}. Cognate with {{och-l|耨|hoe, rake; to weed}}, possibly derived from it with the terminative suffix ''*-ŋ'' for action with a goal, i.e. "to get a field hoed" > "cultivated"; compare {{och-l|亡|to disappear}} from {{och-l|無|(there is) no}} ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

{{zh-ref|Huang (2000)}}, {{zh-ref|Norman (1983)}} and {{zh-ref|Zhou (1986)}} hypothesised that this is the same etymon as {{och-l|儂|person, I, me}}. See there for more.

subSections.title: Readings
Usage notes
subSections.text: For the {{m|en|farmer}} sense, the terms {{m|ja|農家|tr=nōka}} or {{m|ja|農夫|tr=nōfu||male farmer}} or {{m|ja|農婦|tr=nōfu||female farmer}} may be used more often.
